questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased thirst, increased urination, and dry mouth for one month. She has a history of head trauma following a suicide attempt 3 months ago and has bipolar I disorder for which she is being treated with Lithium. She has hand tremors. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 151 mEq/L and an elevated antidiuretic hormone. Urine osmolality is 124 mOsm/kg H2O. Which is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypothalamic Injury due to Head Trauma

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lithium intake This patient has signs of Diabetes Insipidus : Polyuria Polydipsia Nocturia Dehydration elevated Sodium decreased urine osmolality

Highyeild:

Nephrogenic DI is the most common complication of long-term use of lithium , the first-line mood stabilizer for patients with bipolar disorder, as is the case here. Lithium is believed to cause nephrogenic DI by interfering with ADH signalling in the collecting duct cells, which results in reduced expression of water channel aquaporin-2 (AQP2) in these cells and subsequently an elevated ADH in an attempt to compensate.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Hypothalamic injury can result in central DI with low ADH levels. However, this patient's elevated ADH levels suggest nephrogenic DI. Option: B. Elevated ADH levels due to exogenous secretion in patients with paraneoplastic syndrome results in a syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) which, unlike the condition in this patient, manifests as excessive free water retention, euvolemic hyponatremia, and high urine osmolality. Option : C. Individuals with psychogenic polydipsia (PP) also present with polyuria, polydipsia, and low urine osmolality levels , as also seen in this patient. However, PP causes the suppressed release of ADH, low serum Na+, and low serum osmolality levels due to the dilutional effect of excessive water intake. Furthermore, patients with PP do not have dehydration like this patient.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought up because of bizarre behavior and incoherent talkativeness for the past week. The patient says she feels “better than ever” and has a lot of energy. She had absence seizures as a child and tells that valproate had to be discontinued because it damaged her liver. Mental status examination shows pressured and disorganized speech, flight of ideas, lack of insight, and affective lability. Which is the best initial step before deciding on therapy for this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Obtain TSH, Beta-HCG, and serum creatinine concentration

options.label: C
options.text: Assess for suicidal ideation and Echocardiography

options.label: D
options.text: Perform Urine drug testing and begin Cognitive behavioral Therapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Obtain TSH, Beta-HCG, and serum creatinine concentration
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Obtain TSH, Beta-HCG, and serum creatinine concentration This patients' symptoms suggest an acute manic episode of Bipolar disorder . Lithium is a first-line drug for the treatment of an acute manic episode in bipolar disorder.

Highyeild:

However, its use is limited by numerous adverse effects: lithium may induce or worsen pre-existing hypothyroidism by blocking the production and release of L-thyroxine it is a teratogen (increased risk of congenital heart defects like Ebstein anomaly) it may cause lithium nephropathy or worsen chronic kidney disease. Therefore, pregnancy should be ruled out and kidney and thyroid function should be assessed before beginning treatment.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Because agranulocytosis and increased serum transaminase are side effects of valproate , blood tests should be done regularly during pharmacotherapy. Lithium is metabolized and excreted readily , meaning liver function tests would not be required. Option: C. Suicidal ideation is rarely seen during acute manic episodes in bipolar disorder. In contrast, it is a possible clinical feature in depressive episodes. Lithium and some of the other first-line drugs for bipolar disorder may have cardiologic side effects (e.g., prolonged QT intervals, and arrhythmias). ECG before and during treatment is recommended, but echocardiography is not routinely performed before initiating treatment. Option: D. Cognitive behavior therapy is an important component of management in bipolar disorder. However, this patient shows acute manic symptoms, so psychotherapy is difficult to execute in the current situation .

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for affective aggression (hot temper with normal EEG)?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lithium The drugs of choice for affective aggression (hot temper with normal EEG) in order are lithium, serotonergic drugs, anticonvulsants, and low-dose antipsychotics.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B . Low-dose antipsychotics are used in the treatment of affective aggression. Option: C . Imipramine is the drug of choice for the treatment of organic aggression. Option: D . Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for the treatment of ictal aggression (abnormal EEG).

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents complaining of increasing apathy and lethargy, eating and sleeping more over the past several weeks. She states that her alcohol use is limited to two or three beers on occasional weekends. Around 6 months ago, she spent almost 80,000 Rs/- on clothing and other gifts for her boyfriend. Which is the most appropriate single agent to use for pharmacotherapy in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lithium carbonate The patient’s hypersomnia and atypical symptoms of depression , combined with her gender, younger age of onset, and history of a manic episode, point to the depression of bipolar disorder . Therefore, lithium would be the most effective treatment.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A – Alprazolam is a short-acting benzodiazepine, which is not used to treat depression. Option C – Bupropion, a dopamine-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor is not used as a single agent in the depression of bipolar disorder. Option D – Fluoxetine is an SSRI used to treat depression, and would not be appropriate as a single agent to treat a patient with a history of mania.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty with a state of altered sensorium. History revealed that the patient was on lithium treatment for mania. Two days before, he had severe diarrhea and vomiting with abdominal pain. After this, the dose of lithium was continued, with which the vomiting episode increased. In addition, he started complaining of difficulty in speech and walking. On examination, he had coarse tremors and brisk deep tendon reflexes. The cause of this condition is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lithium toxicity Coarse tremors and brisk deep tendon reflexes are symptoms of lithium toxicity. Volume loss due to diarrhea and vomiting in this patient leads to lithium toxicity.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option B – Akathisia is difficulty sitting and standing up from a chair which is an extrapyramidal side effect of typical Option C – Stupor is characterized by a marked decrease in or peculiar motor activity. Option D – Neuroleptic malignant syndrome characteristically presents with a triad of hyperthermia, muscular rigidity, and autonomic instability.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is admitted to the psychiatric unit for treatment. After a few days on medication, she complains of diarrhea, a metallic taste in her mouth, and polyuria. While examining her, the psychiatrist observes a fine intention tremor in her hands. The patient also complains that her psoriasis has flared up. Which of the following medications most likely caused the symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lithium carbonate This patient is experiencing side effects associated with lithium carbonate.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A – The side effects associated with carbamazepine include dizziness, ataxia, sedation, dysarthria, nausea, hyponatremia, cardiovascular conduction problems, aplastic anemia, and agranulocytosis. Option B – Fluoxetine causes nausea, dyspepsia, tremor, nervousness, and increased anxiety during the initial phase of treatment. Option C – Side effects of haloperidol include extrapyramidal symptoms, sedation, weight gain, hyperprolactinemia, and possible neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

questions.text: Lithium was approved by the FDA in 1970 for the management of bipolar disorder. Who found out the effectiveness of Lithium in Bipolar Disorder?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

John Frederick Joseph Cade John Frederick Joseph Cade found out the effectiveness of Lithium in Bipolar Disorder.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A - Sigmund Freud is known for the topographical theory of mind and psychosexual stages of development . Option C - Abraham Harold Maslow proposed the self-actualization theory. Option D - Ugo Cerletti was an Italian neurologist who discovered the method of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).

questions.text: A 37-year-old female diagnosed with bipolar disorder has been started on a mood stabilizer which is also used in the treatment of neutropenia. Which mood stabilizer is being discussed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lithium Lithium is also used in the management of neutropenia, cluster headache, and migraine and is known for its anti-suicidal properties . It is also used as an augmenting agent for treatment-resistant schizophrenia .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A- Oxcarbazepine are NOT used in the treatment of neutropenia . Option B- carbamazepine are NOT used in the treatment of neutropenia . Option D- sodium valproate are NOT used in the treatment of neutropenia .

questions.text: A 25 year-old-man is brought to casualty with a history of being more talkative, reckless spending of money, over cheerfulness, increased grooming, reduced sleep, increased appetite, singing and dancing most of the time from past 10 days, with a similar episode 3 years back. The person should be treated with which of the following drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lithium The patient is having bipolar disorder . He currently is in a manic episode. Lithium is the mood stabilizer among the given options which can be used to treat this patient.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option B- Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine that can be used to treat insomnia in this patient in combination with a mood stabilizer. Option C – Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor that is indicated for the treatment of depression. Option D – Sertraline is used in depression not in the maniac phase of bipolar.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is diagnosed with bipolar disorder, manic type when she was hospitalized after becoming psychotic, hypersexual, severely agitated, and unable to sleep. She is started on medication in the acute phase of her illness. Which of the following medications, recommended for acute use in manic patients, is recommended to be continued on maintenance therapy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lithium Lithium, carbamazepine, and valproic acid are the agents most often used in the long-term maintenance treatment of bipolar disorder.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options :- Options A, B, and D - Antipsychotics (aripiprazole, olanzapine in the options) and benzodiazepines (lorazepam – option B), while very helpful in the acute treatment of bipolar mania, should be discontinued as soon as the patient is in a stable state and not used in long-term maintenance unless absolutely necessary, given the risk of movement disorders and dependence, respectively.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man being treated for bipolar disorder develops a gradual slowing of cognition, with concomitant development of a gravelly voice, constipation, dry skin, and hair loss. The examination is normal, except for a lag in the relaxation phase of the ankle jerk reflex. His only medication is lithium, and his lithium level is 0.62mEq/L. Which of the following tests should most likely be ordered next?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thyroid function tests This patent has several classic symptoms of hypothyroidism . Lithium inhibits secretion by the thyroid gland and may result in hypothyroidism and nontoxic goiter.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A – BUN and creatinine may be elevated secondary to renal complications of lithium. Except for slowed cognition, the patient’s symptoms are not suggestive of uremia. Option B – Lithium levels are within normal limits in this patient (Normal=0.5-1.2mEq/L). Option C – Serum sodium may be elevated in patients taking lithium who develop diabetes insipidus . Hypernatremia may cause mental status changes but none of the other symptoms.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder type I with lithium therapy has come to the clinic because of increased fatigue, weight gain, forgetfulness, and poor concentration in the past couple of weeks. Her lithium level is 1.1mEq and her complete blood count and basic metabolic profile are within normal limits. The most appropriate next step is to?

options.label: A
options.text: Begin treatment with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor

questions.correct_answer: D. Order thyroid stimulating hormone level
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Order thyroid stimulating hormone level The most reasonable step in the management of this patient is to order serum TSH. The symptoms that the patient describes can be a consequence of hypothyroidism due to long-term lithium treatment .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A - Beginning treatment with an SSRI would need to be justified after other medical conditions that can present with depressive-like symptoms are ruled out. Option B - Discontinuing lithium is an inappropriate choice because the patient has a diagnosis of bipolar I disorder and has been stable on the drug of choice for that disorder, which is lithium. Option C - A dexamethasone suppression test has been used in the past to help confirm major depressive disorder since severely depressed patients show non-suppression of cortisol after the administration of dexamethasone.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes because he has been feeling tired, sad, difficulty concentrating for the past 3 months. He denies any recent change in weight, or thoughts of death. He has no significant past medical history or family history and does not take any medications. His vitals are stable. Physical examination is unremarkable. The most appropriate next step is to?

options.label: A
options.text: Advise him to take St. John's Wort and get plenty of exercise and exposure to daylight

options.label: B
options.text: Obtain thyroid function tests, a biochemical profile, and a complete blood count

options.label: D
options.text: Prescribe fluoxetine and ask him to return for reexamination in 2 weeks

questions.correct_answer: B. Obtain thyroid function tests, a biochemical profile, and a complete blood count
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Obtain thyroid function tests, a biochemical profile, and a complete blood count This patient is presenting with symptoms of depression . Laboratory studies should be ordered, including thyroid function tests, a biochemical profile, and a complete blood count.

Highyeild:

Diseases such as hypothyroidism, anemia, diabetes mellitus, and disorders of the kidney, liver, and cardiovascular systems are all associated with depressive symptoms.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A - Taking St. John's Wort and getting plenty of exercise and exposure to daylight may help treat depressive symptoms, but before making any recommendations for his symptoms, he should be evaluated to rule out organic disease . Option C - It is inappropriate to order serum lithium levels as there are no signs of lithium toxicity and it is too most likely unnecessary. Option D - After laboratory studies rule out any abnormalities, it is appropriate to prescribe fluoxetine and ask him to return for a reexamination in 2 weeks. It is not the next step at this time.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder on outpatient therapy with a regimen of lithium carbonate 600 mg by mouth twice a day is brought to the emergency department by ambulance obtunded and ataxic. On examination, she has a tonic-clonic seizure lasting approximately 30 seconds. As part of the laboratory work-up, the patient's lithium level is found to be 4.2 mEq/L. After basic airway and cardiovascular support, the most appropriate next step in this patient's management is to?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer a loading dose of phenytoin

options.label: B
options.text: Get a renal consultation for emergent dialysis

options.label: C
options.text: Order an MRI of the patient's head

options.label: D
options.text: Provide conservative management including fluid and electrolyte replacement

questions.correct_answer: B. Get a renal consultation for emergent dialysis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Get a renal consultation for emergent dialysis The patient presents to the emergency department with potentially life-threatening lithium toxicity . The treatment of choice for lithium levels greater than 4.0 mEq/L is hemodialysis .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A - A loading dose of phenytoin is not indicated after one generalized seizure when the patient's metabolic encephalopathy can be treated with dialysis. Option C - An MRI of the patient's head may be an acceptable follow-up study after the patient receives dialysis, especially if after dialysis treatment the patient continues to have Option D - For lower levels of lithium toxicity, fluid, and electrolyte replacement may be sufficient treatment.
